revision.comment: I added new headings and some content to clarify the different taxonomic categories of fungi found associated with orchids.
revision.text:
'''Orchid mycorrhizae''' are [[symbiotic]] relationships between the [[root]]s of [[plant]]s of the family [[Orchidaceae]] and a variety of [[fungi]]. All orchids are [[myco-heterotrophic]] at some point in their [[Biological life cycle|life cycle]]. Orchid mycorrhizae are critically important during orchid germination, as an orchid seed has virtually no energy reserve and obtains its [[carbon]] from the fungal [[symbiont]].<ref name=mccormick12>{{cite journal| author1=McCormick, M. K. |author2=Lee Taylor, D. |author3=Juhaszova, K. |author4=Burnett, R. K. |author5=Whigham, D. F. |author6=O’Neill, J. P.| year=2012| title=Limitations on orchid recruitment: not a simple picture| journal=Molecular Ecology| volume=21|issue=6 | pages=1511–1523| doi=10.1111/j.1365-294X.2012.05468.x| pmid=22272942}}</ref><ref name=":6" />
The symbiosis starts with a structure called a protocorm''.''<ref name="Peterson" >{{Cite book |title=Mycorrhizas : anatomy and cell biology |last=Peterson |first=R. Larry |date=2004|publisher=NRC Research Press |last2=Massicotte |first2=Hugues B. |last3=Melville |first3=Lewis H. |isbn=978-0851999012|location=Ottawa|oclc=57587171}}</ref> During the symbiosis, the fungus develops structures, called pelotons, within the root cortex of the orchid.<ref name="Smith">{{Cite book |title=Mycorrhizal symbiosis|last=Smith |first=S. E. |date=1997|publisher=Academic Press |last2=Read |first2=D. J. |last3=Harley |first3=J. L. |isbn=978-0126528404 |edition=2nd |location=San Diego, Calif. |oclc=35637899}}</ref>
Many adult orchids retain their fungal symbionts, although the benefits to the adult [[photosynthetic]] orchid and the fungus remain largely unexplored.
==Seed germination == [[File:Anacamptis fragrans.JPG|thumb|Orchid protocorm]] Orchids have several life stages. The first stage is the non-germinated orchid seed, the next stage is the protocorm, and the following stage is the adult orchid. Orchid seeds are very small 0.35mm to 1.50mm long), spindle-shaped, and have an opening at the pointed end.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Arditti|first=Joseph|last2=Michaud|first2=Justine D.|last3=Healey|first3=Patrick L.|date=1979|title=Morphometry of Orchid Seeds. I. Paphiopedilum and Native California and Related Species of Cypripedium|jstor=2442211|journal=American Journal of Botany|volume=66|issue=10|pages=1128–1137|doi=10.2307/2442211}}</ref> Each seed has an embryo that is undifferentiated and lacks root and shoot [[meristem]]s.<ref name="Peterson"/> An orchid seed does not have enough nutritional support to grow on its own.<ref name=":6" /> Instead, it gets nutrients needed for germination from outside sources. In nature, the nutritional support comes from a fungal partner.<ref name="Smith"/> When the orchid seeds geminate, they form seedling structures called protocorms which consist of [[parenchyma]] cells.<ref name="Minasiewicz"/><ref name="Peterson" /> Infected protocorms tend to develop an active meristem within a few days.<ref name="Hadley"/> In the adult stage, many orchids have a small amount of thick unbranched roots which results in a root system with a small surface area that is favorable to potentially mycotrophic tissue.<ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|last=Rasmussen|first=Hanne N.|last2=Whigham|first2=Dennis F.|date=2002-06-01|title=Phenology of roots and mycorrhiza in orchid species differing in phototrophic strategy|journal=New Phytologist|language=en|volume=154|issue=3|pages=797–807 |doi=10.1046/j.1469-8137.2002.00422.x|issn=1469-8137}}</ref>
Orchids lacking chlorophyll, called achlorophyllous MHPs, will retain their fungal symbionts their entire lives, relying on the fungus for carbon.<ref name=":02">{{Cite journal|last=McKendrick|first=S. L.|last2=Leake|first2=J. R.|last3=Taylor|first3=D. Lee|last4=Read|first4=D. J.|date=2002-04-01|title=Symbiotic germination and development of the myco-heterotrophic orchid Neottia nidus-avis in nature and its requirement for locally distributed Sebacina spp|journal=New Phytologist|language=en|volume=154|issue=1|pages=233–247|doi=10.1046/j.1469-8137.2002.00372.x|issn=1469-8137}}</ref> The debate over whether fungal symbiosis is necessary for the orchid is an old one, as Noel Bernard first proposed orchid symbiosis in 1899. In 1922 the American botanist Lewis Knudson discovered that orchid seeds could be grown on agar and fungal sugars without mycorrhizae, however modern research has found that the germination of orchids may be more successful with the actual fungus.<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Alghamdi|first=Sameera A.|title=Influence of mycorrhizal fungi on seed germination and growth in terrestrial and epiphytic orchids|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S1319562X1730270X|journal=Saudi Journal of Biological Sciences|doi=10.1016/j.sjbs.2017.10.021|year=2017}}</ref>
Although [[Epiphyte|epiphytic]] orchids grow on other plants they may produce chlorophyll in their leaves, stems, and roots. As with all orchids, germination and the develop into protocorms, young plants which have germinated but lack leaves, is reliant upon fungal symbionts, which decrease the time of germination and increase the vigor of the protocorm'''.'''<ref name=":3" /> The reliance of orchids on specific fungi has been widely studied, and the populations of certain fungi which are present in the soil have proved to be of greater importance in seed germination than the orchid's proximity to older plants or their geographical location, as previously assumed.<ref>McCormick, M. K., Taylor, D. L., Whigham, D. F. and Burnett, R. K. (2016), Germination patterns in three terrestrial orchids relate to abundance of mycorrhizal fungi. J Ecol, 104: 744–754. doi:10.1111/1365-2745.12556</ref>
== Fungal entry into orchid == The fungus can enter at various orchid life stages. Fungal hyphae can penetrate the parenchyma cells of geminated orchid seeds, protocorms, late-staged seedlings, or adult plant roots.<ref>{{Cite book |title=Molecular mycorrhizal symbiosis |last=Martin |first=Francis |isbn=9781118951415|location=Hoboken, New Jersey|oclc=958205579|date=2016-12-19 }}</ref> The fungal hyphae that enter the orchid have many mitochondria and few vacuoles.<ref name=":5">{{Cite journal |last=Peterson|first=R. L.|last2=Currah|first2=R. S.|date=1990-05-01|title=Synthesis of mycorrhizae between protocorms of Goodyera repens (Orchidaceae) and Ceratobasidium cereale|journal=Canadian Journal of Botany|volume=68|issue=5|pages=1117–1125|doi=10.1139/b90-141|issn=0008-4026}}</ref> In the protocorm stage, hyphae enter the chalazal (top) end of the embryo.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Leake|first=Jonathan R.|date=1994|title=Tansley Review No. 69. The Biology of Myco-Heterotrophic ('Saprophytic') Plants|url=|journal=The New Phytologist|volume=127|issue=2|pages=171–216|doi=10.1111/j.1469-8137.1994.tb04272.x|doi-broken-date=|jstor=2558021|via=}}</ref> In terrestrial orchids, fungal entry into adult plant roots happens mainly through root hair tips, which then take on a distorted shape.<ref name=":6">{{Cite journal |last=Sathiyadash|first=Kullaiyan|last2=Muthukumar|first2=Thangavelu|last3=Uma|first3=Eswaranpillai|last4=Pandey|first4=Radha Raman|date=2012-09-01|title=Mycorrhizal association and morphology in orchids |journal=Journal of Plant Interactions|volume=7|issue=3|pages=238–247|doi=10.1080/17429145.2012.699105|issn=1742-9145}}</ref> Typically, the partnership is maintained throughout the lifetime of the orchid because they depend on the fungus for nutrients including minerals.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Pecoraro|first=L.|last2=Girlanda|first2=M.|last3=Kull|first3=T.|last4=Perini|first4=C.|last5=Perotto|first5=S.|date=2012-12-01|title=Molecular identification of root fungal associates in Orchis pauciflora Tenore |journal=Plant Biosystems - an International Journal Dealing with All Aspects of Plant Biology|volume=146|issue=4|pages=985–991|doi=10.1080/11263504.2011.634447|issn=1126-3504}}</ref> However, some orchids have been found to switch fungal partners during extreme conditions.<ref name=":72"/>
=== Fungal pelotons and orchid root cortex === Shortly after the fungus enters an orchid, the fungus produces intracellular hyphal coils, called pelotons, in the embryos of developing seedlings and the roots of adult plants.<ref name="Smith" /> The formation of pelotons in root cortical cells is a defining anatomical structure in orchid mycorrhiza that differentiate it from other forms of mycorrhiza.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Rasmussen|first=Hanne N.|date=2002|title=Recent developments in the study of orchid mycorrhiza|jstor=24130393|journal=Plant and Soil|volume=244|issue=1/2|pages=149–163|doi=10.2307/24130393|doi-broken-date=2018-09-25}}</ref> The pelotons can range in size and in the loose or tight packaging of their hyphae.<ref name="Hadley">{{Cite journal|last=Hadley|first=G.|last2=Williamson|first2=B.|date=1971-05-01|title=Analysis of the Post-Infection Growth Stimulus in Orchid Mycorrhiza|journal=New Phytologist|language=en|volume=70|issue=3|pages=445–455|doi=10.1111/j.1469-8137.1971.tb02546.x|issn=1469-8137}}</ref> Pelotons of live fungal hyphae are eventually disintegrated, or lysed, and become brown or yellow clumps in the orchid cells.<ref name="Minasiewicz">{{Cite journal|last=Selosse|first=Marc-André|last2=Minasiewicz|first2=Julita|last3=Boullard|first3=Bernard|date=2017-08-01|title=An annotated translation of Noël Bernard's 1899 article 'On the germination of Neottia nidus-avis'|journal=Mycorrhiza|language=en|volume=27|issue=6|pages=611–618|doi=10.1007/s00572-017-0774-z|pmid=28421312|issn=0940-6360}}</ref> The disintegrated pelotons are an area of considerable interest in current research. The disintegrated pelotons first experience a collapse where orchid microtubules surround the pelotons, which may be the mechanism behind the peloton collapse by producing physiological and structural changes of the hyphae.<ref name=":7">{{Cite journal|last=Uetake|first=Yukari|last2=Farquhar|first2=Melissa L.|last3=Peterson|first3=R. Larry|date=1997-04-01|title=Changes in microtubule arrays in symbiotic orchid protocorms during fungal colonization and senescence|journal=New Phytologist|language=en|volume=135|issue=4|pages=701–709|doi=10.1046/j.1469-8137.1997.00686.x|issn=1469-8137}}</ref> The cortical cells of older roots tend to have more lysed pelotons than young pelotons.<ref name=":6" /> Although pelotons are lysed, new pelotons continue to be formed, which indicates a high amount of entering hyphal activity.<ref name=":4" /> Pelotons are separated from the orchid's cytoplasm by an interfacial matrix and the orchid's plasma membrane.<ref name=":7" /> The material that makes up the interfacial matrix can differ depending on the orchid mychorrizal stage of interaction.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Peterson|first=R. Larry|last2=Uetake|first2=Yukari|last3=Bonfante|first3=Paola|last4=Faccio|first4=Antonella|date=1996-12-01|title=The interface between fungal hyphae and orchid protocorm cells|journal=Canadian Journal of Botany|volume=74|issue=12|pages=1861–1870|doi=10.1139/b96-223|issn=0008-4026}}</ref> Orchid cells with degenerating pelotons lack starch grains, whereas the newly invaded orchid cells contain large starch grains, suggesting the hydrolysis of starch resulting from the fungal colonization.<ref name=":5" /> There is an enlargement of the nucleus in infected orchid cortical cells and in non-infected cortical cells near an infected area as a result of increased DNA content.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hadley|first=G.|last2=Williamson|first2=B.|date=1972-11-01|title=Features of Mycorrhizal Infection in Some Malayan Orchids|journal=New Phytologist|language=en|volume=71|issue=6|pages=1111–1118|doi=10.1111/j.1469-8137.1972.tb01989.x|issn=1469-8137}}</ref> The increased DNA content has been correlated with the differentiation of parenchyma cells suggesting its role in orchid growth.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Alvarez|first=Marvin R.|date=1968|title=Quantitative Changes in Nuclear DNA Accompanying Postgermination Embryonic Development in Vanda (Orchidaceae)|jstor=2440469|journal=American Journal of Botany|volume=55|issue=9|pages=1036–1041|doi=10.2307/2440469}}</ref>
== Fungi forming orchid mycorrhizae == '''Basidiomycetous Rhizoctonia Fungi'''
The fungi that form orchid mycorrhizae are typically [[basidiomycetes]]. These fungi come from a range of taxa including ''[[Ceratobasidium]]'' ([[Rhizoctonia]]), ''[[Sebacina]]'', ''[[Tulasnella]]'' and ''[[Russula]]'' species. Most orchids associate with [[saprotrophic]] or [[pathogenic]] fungi, while a few associate with [[ectomycorrhizal]] fungal species. These latter associations are often called tripartite associations as they involve the orchid, the ectomycorrhizal fungus and its photosynthetic host plant. Some of the challenges in determining host-specificity in orchid mycorrhizae have been the methods of identifying the orchid-specific fungi from other free living fungal species in wild-sourced samples. Even with modern molecular analysis and genomic databases, this can still prove difficult,<ref name=":2">McCormick, M. K., Whigham, D. F. and O'Neill, J. (2004), Mycorrhizal diversity in photosynthetic terrestrial orchids. New Phytologist, 163: 425–438. doi:10.1111/j.1469-8137.2004.01114.x</ref> partially due to the difficulty in culturing fungi from protocorms and identification of fungal samples,<ref name=":2" /> as well as changes in evolving rDNA.<ref name=":62">{{Cite journal|last=Jacquemyn|first=Hans|last2=Honnay|first2=Olivier|last3=Cammue|first3=Bruno P. A.|last4=Brys|first4=Rein|last5=Lievens|first5=Bart|date=2010-09-01 |title=Low specificity and nested subset structure characterize mycorrhizal associations in five closely related species of the genus Orchis|journal=Molecular Ecology|language=en|volume=19|issue=18|pages=4086–4095|doi=10.1111/j.1365-294x.2010.04785.x|pmid=20735736|issn=1365-294X}}</ref> However it has become clearer that different fungi may associate with orchids at specific stages, whether at germination or protocorm development, or throughout their life.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Shefferson|first=Richard P. |last2=Weiß|first2=Michael |last3=Kull|first3=Tiiu |last4=Taylor|first4=D. Lee|date=2005-02-01|title=High specificity generally characterizes mycorrhizal association in rare lady's slipper orchids, genus Cypripedium|journal=Molecular Ecology|language=en|volume=14|issue=2|pages=613–626|doi=10.1111/j.1365-294x.2005.02424.x|pmid=15660950 |issn=1365-294X}}</ref> The types of orchids and their symbiotic fungi also vary depending on the environmental niches they occupy, whether terrestrial or growing on other plants as an [[epiphyte]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Alghamdi|first=Sameera A.|title=Influence of mycorrhizal fungi on seed germination and growth in terrestrial and epiphytic orchids |journal=Saudi Journal of Biological Sciences|doi=10.1016/j.sjbs.2017.10.021|year=2017}}</ref>
'''Ectomycorrhizal Basidiomycota'''
A number of other basidiomycetous fungi have been documented in various orchids that do not fall under the Rhizoctonia umbrella. In particular, many fully mycoheterotrophic orchids associate with ectomycorrhizal basidiomycetes belonging to genera such as Thelephora, Tomentella and Russula.
'''Basidiomycetes of the Atractiellales'''
'''Ascomycota'''
Though rare in orchids, ascomycete associations have been documented in several orchid species. The European terrestrial orchid Epipactis helleborine has a specific association with ectomycorrhizal ascomycetes in the Tuberaceae.
== Symbiont specificity == Current molecular analysis has allowed for the identification of specific taxa forming symbiotic relationships which are of interest in the study, cultivation, and conservation of orchids. This is especially important in the trade and preservation endangered species or orchids of commercial value like the [[vanilla bean]].<ref name=":42">{{Cite journal|last=Swarts|first=Nigel D.|last2=Dixon|first2=Kingsley W.|title=Perspectives on orchid conservation in botanic gardens|journal=Trends in Plant Science|language=en-US|volume=14|issue=11|pages=590–598|doi=10.1016/j.tplants.2009.07.008|pmid=19733499|year=2009}}</ref> There have been seen trends in the type of symbioses found in orchids, depending primarily on the life-style of the orchid, as the symbiosis is primarily of benefit to the plant. Terrestrial orchids have been found to commonly associate with [[Tulasnellaceae]], however some [[autotroph]]ic and non-autotrophic orchids do associate with several ectomycorrhizal fungi.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Bidartondo|first=Martin I. |last2=Burghardt|first2=Bastian |last3=Gebauer|first3=Gerhard |last4=Bruns|first4=Thomas D.|last5=Read|first5=David J.|date=2004|title=Changing Partners in the Dark: Isotopic and Molecular Evidence of Ectomycorrhizal Liaisons between Forest Orchids and Trees |jstor=4142864|journal=Proceedings: Biological Sciences|volume=271|issue=1550|pages=1799–1806}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=McKendrick|first=S. L.|last2=Leake|first2=J. R.|last3=Read|first3=D. J. |date=2000 |title=Symbiotic Germination and Development of Myco-Heterotrophic Plants in Nature: Transfer of Carbon from Ectomycorrhizal Salix repens and Betula pendula to the Orchid Corallorhiza trifida Through Shared Hyphal Connections |jstor=2588821|journal=The New Phytologist|volume=145|issue=3|pages=539–548}}</ref> [[Epiphytic fungus|Epiphytic fungi]], however, may associate more commonly with limited clades of ''rhizoctonia'', a polyphyletic grouping.<ref name=":52">{{Cite journal|last=Martos|first=Florent|last2=Munoz|first2=François|last3=Pailler|first3=Thierry|last4=Kottke|first4=Ingrid|last5=Gonneau|first5=Cédric|last6=Selosse|first6=Marc-André |date=2012-10-01|title=The role of epiphytism in architecture and evolutionary constraint within mycorrhizal networks of tropical orchids|journal=Molecular Ecology|language=en|volume=21|issue=20|pages=5098–5109|doi=10.1111/j.1365-294x.2012.05692.x|pmid=22765763|issn=1365-294X}}</ref> These fungi may form significant symbioses with either an epiphytic or terrestrial orchid, but rarely do they associate with both.<ref name=":52" /> Using seed-baiting techniques researchers have been able to isolate specific species and strains of symbiotic orchid mycorrhizae. Using this technique seeds of the epiphytic orchid ''[[Dendrobium aphyllum]]'' were found to germinate to seedlings when paired with fungal strains of ''Tulasnella'', however, seeds of this species did not germinate when treated with ''[[Trichoderma]]'' fungi taken from adult orchids, indicating there are stage specific symbionts. These fungal symbioses, as well as their affinity towards specific symbionts, vary based on the stage of development and age of the host roots<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Zi|first=Xiao-Meng|last2=Sheng|first2=Chun-Ling|last3=Goodale|first3=Uromi Manage|last4=Shao|first4=Shi-Cheng|last5=Gao|first5=Jiang-Yun|date=2014-10-01|title=In situ seed baiting to isolate germination-enhancing fungi for an epiphytic orchid, Dendrobium aphyllum (Orchidaceae)|journal=Mycorrhiza|language=en|volume=24|issue=7|pages=487–499|doi=10.1007/s00572-014-0565-8 |pmid=24563211|issn=0940-6360}}</ref><ref name=":02"/><ref name=":1" /> As an orchid ages the fungal associations become more complex.
[[Mixotroph]]ic orchids like ''Cephalanthera longibracteata'' may associate generally with several fungi, most notably from ''[[Russulaceae]],[[Tricholomataceae]], [[Sebacinales]], [[Thelephoraceae]].'',<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Sakamoto |first=Yuki |last2=Yokoyama |first2=Jun |last3=Maki |first3=Masayuki |title=Mycorrhizal diversity of the orchid Cephalanthera longibracteata in Japan |journal=Mycoscience |volume=56 |issue=2 |pages=183–189 |doi=10.1016/j.myc.2014.06.002|year=2015 }}</ref> as they do not depend as heavily on the fungus for carbon. Some orchids can be very specific in their symbionts, preferring a single class or genus of fungi. Genotypes of ''[[Corallorhiza maculata]],'' a [[Myco-heterotrophy|myco-heterotrophic]] orchid, have been found to closely associate with ''Russulaceae'' regardless of geological location or the presence of other orchids.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Taylor|first=D. Lee|last2=Bruns|first2=Thomas D.|last3=Hodges|first3=Scott A.|date=2004-01-07|title=Evidence for mycorrhizal races in a cheating orchid |url=http://rspb.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/271/1534/35 |journal=Proceedings of the Royal Society of London B: Biological Sciences |language=en |volume=271 |issue=1534 |pages=35–43 |doi=10.1098/rspb.2003.2557 |issn=0962-8452 |pmid=15002769|pmc=1691555}}</ref> The terrestrial Chilean orchids ''Chloraea collicensis'' and ''C. gavilu'' have been found to have only one key symbiont in the genus ''Rhizoctonia''.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Pereira |first=Guillermo |last2=Romero |first2=Christian |last3=Suz |first3=Laura M. |last4=Atala |first4=Cristian |title=Essential mycorrhizal partners of the endemic Chilean orchids Chloraea collicensis and C. gavilu |journal=Flora - Morphology, Distribution, Functional Ecology of Plants |volume=209 |issue=2 |pages=95–99 |doi=10.1016/j.flora.2013.12.001|year=2014 }}</ref> Research suggests that orchids which are considered to be generalists will associate with other generalist fungi, often with several species, however orchids with high degrees of specialization will have less fungal associations.<ref name=":62" />
The environment may also affect the fungal symbiosis, with differences in tropical versus temperate orchids. The photosynthetic orchid ''[[Goodyera pubescens]]'' was found to associate with only one dominate fungus, unless subjected to changes in the environment, like drought, in which case the orchid was able to change symbionts in response to stresses.<ref name=":72">{{Cite journal |last=McCormick |first=Melissa K. |last2=Whigham |first2=Dennis F. |last3=Sloan |first3=Dan |last4=O'Malley |first4=Kelly |last5=Hodkinson |first5=Brendan |date=2006-04-01 |title=Orchid–Fungus Fidelity: A Marriage Meant to Last? |journal=Ecology |language=en |volume=87 |issue=4 |pages=903–911 |doi=10.1890/0012-9658(2006)87[903:ofammt]2.0.co;2 |issn=1939-9170}}</ref> This is unique in that it conflicts with the trends seen in most [[Arbuscular mycorrhiza|arbuscular]] and ectomycorrhizal symbioses which form associations with several fungi at the same time.<ref name=":72" />
The knowledge of species-specific fungal symbionts is crucial given the endangered status of many orchids around the world. The identification of their fungal symbionts could prove useful in the preservation and reintroduction of threatened orchids.<ref name=":42" /> Researchers in India have used samples from adult orchids to germinate seeds from an endangered orchid ''[[Dactylorhiza hatagirea]]'' which were found to associate closely with ''[[Ceratobasidium]].''<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Aggarwal, Simmi|first=Zettler, Lawrence W.|date=2010|title=Reintroduction of an endangered terrestrial orchid, Dactylorhiza hatagirea (D. Don) Soo, assisted by symbiotic seed germination-First report from the Indian subcontinent |journal=Nature and Science |volume=8 |issue=10 |pages=139–145 |via=ResearchGate |url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/290162421 }}</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == * "Orchid Mycorrhiza", from ''Fungal Biology'' (online textbook), School of Biological Sciences, [[University of Sydney]], June 2004: ** [http://bugs.bio.usyd.edu.au/learning/resources/Mycology/Plant_Interactions/Mycorrhizas/Orchid/orchidFunction.shtml "Function of Orchid Mycorrhizas"] ** [http://bugs.bio.usyd.edu.au/learning/resources/Mycology/Plant_Interactions/Mycorrhizas/Orchid/orchidSymbionts.shtml "Symbionts of Orchid Mycorrhiza"] * [http://botit.botany.wisc.edu/courses/mpp/OrchidMyco116.html "Orchidoid mycorrhizae"] from Mycorrhizae and Plant Phylogeny (website) by Frank C. Landis, Botany Department, [[University of Wisconsin–Madison]], January 11, 2002.
{{DEFAULTSORT:Orchid Mycorrhiza}} [[Category:Symbiosis]] [[Category:Soil biology]] [[Category:Orchid morphology]] [[Category:Myco-heterotrophic orchids| ]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2014}} {{Infobox person | honorific_prefix = | name = Philip Mould | honorific_suffix = [[Order of the British Empire|OBE]] | image = Philip Mould.jpg | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = 1960 <!-- {{Birth date|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | birth_place = | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} (death date then birth date) --> | death_place = | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = <!-- {{Coord|LAT|LONG|display=inline}} --> | monuments = | residence = | nationality = English | other_names = | education = | alma_mater = [[University of East Anglia]] | occupation = {{Unbulleted list| [[Art dealer]] | [[Art history|art historian]] }} | years_active = | employer = | organization = | agent = | known_for = | notable_works = | style = | influences = | influenced = | home_town = | television = | religion = | spouse = | partner = | children = | parents = | relatives = | awards = | website = {{URL|www.philipmould.com}} }} '''Philip Jonathan Clifford Mould''' [[Order of the British Empire|OBE]] (born 1960) is an English [[art dealer]], writer and broadcaster.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/art/art-features/5526015/-confessions-of-an-art-sleuth.html|title=Philip Mould: why I love being a sleuth on art's treasure trail|last=Mould|first=By Philip|newspaper=Telegraph.co.uk|access-date=2017-02-14|language=en}}</ref> He has made a number of major art discoveries, including some of [[Thomas Gainsborough]]'s earliest known works,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/art/art-news/5407381/Rare-Gainsborough-uncovered-by-Antiques-Roadshow-presenter.html|title=Rare Gainsborough uncovered by Antiques Roadshow presenter|last=Millward|first=By David|newspaper=Telegraph.co.uk|access-date=2017-02-14|language=en}}</ref> the only known portrait of [[Arthur, Prince of Wales]]<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/d/Books/Trail-Lot-163-Search-Lost-Art-Treasures/1857025237|title=The Trail of Lot 163: In Search of Lost Art Treasures|last=Mould|first=Philip|date=1997-03-13|publisher=Fourth Estate|isbn=9781857025231|location=London|language=English}}</ref> and a number of lost works by [[Anthony van Dyck|Sir Anthony Van Dyck]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2011/jun/11/saleroom-sleuth-unearthed-van-dycks|title=Van Dyck paintings unearthed by saleroom sleuth|last=Alberge|first=Dalya|date=2011-06-11|newspaper=The Guardian|access-date=2017-02-14|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref>
Mould is the author of two books on art discovery and is widely consulted by the media on the subject. He is well known for his role co-presenting the BBC television programme ''[[Fake or Fortune?]]'', the most watched arts programme on television.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/its-a-copy-fake-or-fortune-stars-try-to-halt-rival-show-6gstpwtrz|title=It’s a copy: Fake or Fortune? stars try to halt rival show|access-date=2017-02-14|language=en}}</ref>
==Biography==
[[File:Anglo-Flemish School, Arthur, Prince of Wales (Granard portrait) -003.png|thumb|right|upright|Portrait of [[Arthur, Prince of Wales]] (1486–1502) reidentified by Mould]]
Mould was educated at [[Kingsmead School, Hoylake]], [[Worth School]] and the [[University of East Anglia]] from where he graduated with a BA in History of Art in 1981.<ref>'MOULD, Philip Jonathan Clifford', Who's Who 2014, A & C Black, an imprint of Bloomsbury Publishing plc, 2014; online edn, Oxford University Press, Dec 2013</ref>
Mould's father owned a factory in Liverpool and his family was based in the Wirral.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/celebritynews/my-perfect-weekend/10560561/My-perfect-weekend-Philip-Mould-art-sleuth.html|title=My perfect weekend: Philip Mould, art sleuth|newspaper=Telegraph.co.uk|access-date=2017-02-14|language=en}}</ref> He developed an interest in antiques at an early age, thanks to his mother. She contracted polio as a child, and was in a wheelchair so would send Philip, aged six, into antiques shops to bring things out to her for inspection.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/femail/article-3827475/I-sold-signed-copy-John-Lennon-s-Mind-Games-50p-Philip-Mould-gives-definitive-answers-probing-questions.html|title=The definite article: This week it’s host Philip Mould|newspaper=Mail Online|access-date=2017-02-14}}</ref> Mould made friends with the owner of a local antiques shop, who taught him to read hallmarks on silver when he was just 11 or 12 years old, and by the age of 14 he was dealing in antique silver.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/celebritynews/my-perfect-weekend/10560561/My-perfect-weekend-Philip-Mould-art-sleuth.html|title=My perfect weekend: Philip Mould, art sleuth|newspaper=Telegraph.co.uk|access-date=2017-02-14|language=en}}</ref>
Mould began art dealing in his early teens and has since established a leading art dealership specialising in British art, a subject on which he is internationally consulted.<ref>{{cite web|last=Bennett |first=Will |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1521012/Lost-portrait-reveals-the-soft-side-of-Elizabeth-I.html |title=Telegraph 12 June 2006 |publisher=Telegraph.co.uk |date=12 June 2006 |accessdate=6 May 2011}}</ref> He has sold works to public institutions such as [[Metropolitan Museum of Art|The Metropolitan Museum of Art]] (New York),<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/426019|title=John Vanderbank, the younger {{!}} Self-Portrait {{!}} The Met|website=The Metropolitan Museum of Art, i.e. The Met Museum|access-date=2017-02-14}}</ref> [[National Portrait Gallery (London)]], [[Museum of Fine Arts, Boston|Museum of Fine Arts Boston]],<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.mfa.org/collections/object/portrait-of-a-lady-as-a-shepherdess-563890|title=Portrait of a Lady as a Shepherdess|date=2017-02-05|newspaper=Museum of Fine Arts, Boston|access-date=2017-02-14|language=en}}</ref> [[Tate]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.tate.org.uk/art/artworks/richardson-portrait-of-the-artists-son-jonathan-richardson-the-younger-in-his-study-t13207|title="Portrait of the Artist’s Son, Jonathan Richardson the Younger, in his Study", Jonathan Richardson c.1734 {{!}} Tate|last=Tate|website=Tate|language=en-GB|access-date=2017-02-14}}</ref> [[Huntington Library|The Huntington]] (California),<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://emuseum.huntington.org/objects/12419/portrait-of-a-young-child?ctx=1dcfd205-5a0e-4d8f-8a1d-87aac4595541&idx=0|title=Portrait of a Young Child – Works – The Huntington Art Collections Online Catalog|website=emuseum.huntington.org|access-date=2017-02-14}}</ref> and the [[Royal Albert Memorial Museum]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.artfund.org/artsaved/search/philip+mould |title=The Art Fund, 'Art Saved' |publisher=Artfund.org |date= |accessdate=6 May 2011}}</ref>
Mould has worked as a valuer for the [[Heritage Lottery Fund]] and the Government's [[Acceptance in Lieu]] scheme. Between 1988–2010 he acted as honorary art adviser to the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|House of Commons]] and the [[House of Lords]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Bennett |first=Will |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/4722257/Bringing-art-into-politics.html |title=Telegraph 19 March 2001 |publisher=Telegraph.co.uk |date=19 March 2001 |accessdate=6 May 2011}}</ref> He is president of the charity Kids in Museums,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://kidsinmuseums.org.uk/about/trustees/ |title=Kids in Museums website |publisher=Google.com |date= |accessdate=22 May 2012}}</ref> president and ex-chairman of [[Plantlife International]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.plantlife.org.uk/about_us/our_team/our_trustees/ |title=Plantlife International website |publisher=Plantlife.org.uk |date= |accessdate=22 May 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120504094135/http://www.plantlife.org.uk/about_us/our_team/our_trustees/ |archivedate=4 May 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> a patron of [[Fight for Sight (UK)|Fight for Sight]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://fightforsight.org.uk/press-release/items/philip-mould-obe-joins-fight-for-sight-as-patron-327|title=Philip Mould OBE joins Fight for Sight as patron – Fight for Sight|last=|first=|year=2013|work=fightforsight.org.uk|accessdate=19 May 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140325113323/http://fightforsight.org.uk/press-release/items/philip-mould-obe-joins-fight-for-sight-as-patron-327|archivedate=25 March 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref> and a trustee and director of the [[Tony Banks, Baron Stratford|Tony Banks]] Memorial Trust for the acquisition of historical works for museums.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tonybanks.org/ |title=Tony Banks Memorial Trust|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110926094647/http://www.tonybanks.org/|archivedate=26 September 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.endole.co.uk/company/06208857/the-tony-banks-memorial-trust-limited |title=The Tony Banks Memorial Trust Limited - Company Information - Endole |first= |last= |work=endole.co.uk |year=2015 |accessdate=4 September 2015}}</ref> Mould is also a supporter of CleanupUK, and Pond Conservation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pondconservation.org.uk/about/News/pressreleases/millionpondsprojectlaunch/|title=Pond Conservation website|publisher=pondconservation.org.uk|date=|accessdate=22 May 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131203082735/http://www.pondconservation.org.uk/about/News/pressreleases/millionpondsprojectlaunch/|archivedate=3 December 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref> He was elected as a fellow of the [[Linnean Society]] in 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://linnean.org/|title=The Linnean Society website|publisher=linnean.org |date= |accessdate=31 May 2012}}</ref>
Mould is a regular broadcaster, reviewer and writer for the national press. His television work includes writing and presenting the [[Channel 4]] series ''Changing Faces,'' and featuring as an expert on the ''[[Antiques Roadshow]].'' In 2011, he began co-hosting the television programme ''[[Fake or Fortune?]]'' with [[Fiona Bruce]].<ref name="FoF">{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b01mxxz6|title=Fake or Fortune?|publisher=[[BBC Online]]|accessdate=4 June 2013}}</ref> ''Fake or Fortune?'' now ranks as television's most popular arts show - regularly drawing an audience of 5 million - and has an international following.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/its-a-copy-fake-or-fortune-stars-try-to-halt-rival-show-6gstpwtrz|title=It’s a copy: Fake or Fortune? stars try to halt rival show|access-date=2017-02-14|language=en}}</ref>
In January 2014, Mould warned of the increasing prevalence of what he termed "trapping" in which crooked sellers misleadingly hint that fake artworks have genuine provenance, without actually making false descriptions or asserting attributions.<ref name="Copping">{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/art/art-news/10566055/Art-experts-warn-of-the-rise-of-the-trappers.html|title=Art experts warn of the rise of the 'trappers'|last=Copping|first=Jasper|date=12 January 2014|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|accessdate=13 January 2014}}</ref>
Mould is the author of two critically acclaimed books on art discovery, which are frequently cited as illuminating and well told insights into the workings of the old master trade, and have been published in America, Japan and China.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/books/bookreviews/5567418/Sleuth-The-Amazing-Quest-for-Lost-Art-Treasures-by-Philip-Mould-review.html|title=Sleuth: The Amazing Quest for Lost Art Treasures by Philip Mould: review|last=Reid|first=By Aileen|newspaper=Telegraph.co.uk|access-date=2017-02-14|language=en}}</ref>
In recognition of his art world expertise and contribution to portrait heritage he was created [[Officer of the Order of the British Empire|OBE]] in the [[2005 New Year Honours]] list.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.britishtheatreguide.info/news/nyhons05.htm |title=The British Theatre Guide: New Year Honours List 2005 |publisher=Britishtheatreguide.info |date=4 January 2005 |accessdate=6 May 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050122024515/http://www.britishtheatreguide.info/news/nyhons05.htm |archivedate=22 January 2005 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> For his achievements in his field, as well as his involvement with numerous charities and broadcasting, Mould received an [[honorary doctorate]] in July 2013 at his [[Alma mater|former university]], the [[University of East Anglia]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.uea.ac.uk/mac/comm/media/press/2013/May/hon-grads|title=UEA to honour notable alumni at its 50th anniversary graduation|date=21 May 2013|publisher=University of East Anglia|accessdate=13 January 2014}}</ref>
In August 2014, Mould was one of 200 public figures who were signatories to a letter to ''[[The Guardian]]'' opposing [[Scottish independence]] in the run-up to September's [[Scottish independence referendum, 2014|referendum on that issue]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2014/aug/07/celebrities-open-letter-scotland-independence-full-text |title=Celebrities' open letter to Scotland – full text and list of signatories | Politics |publisher=theguardian.com |date=2014-08-07 |accessdate=26 June 2014}}</ref>
In October 2015 Mould appeared on BBC's ''[[Gardeners' World]]'', in the garden of his home, discussing his passion for nature and talked of his interest in varieties of rose which would have been grown in the time of [[Anthony van Dyck|Sir Anthony van Dyck]]. He also discussed the work of one of his favourite artists, [[Cedric Morris]], who was also a great [[plantsman]].<ref>{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b06h3zs2 |title=BBC Two - Gardeners' World, 2015, Episode 29 |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=9 October 2015 |accessdate=9 October 2015}}</ref> Mould is a keen collector of Morris's work (for his private collection), and champions modern British artists in general; he cites the [[Bloomsbury Group]] amongst his favourites.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/celebritynews/my-perfect-weekend/10560561/My-perfect-weekend-Philip-Mould-art-sleuth.html|title=My perfect weekend: Philip Mould, art sleuth|newspaper=Telegraph.co.uk|access-date=2017-02-14|language=en}}</ref>
== Bibliography == * {{cite book |date=1995 |title=Sleepers: In Search of Lost Old Masters |location=London |publisher=Fourth Estate |isbn=978-1857022186 }}, retitled in paperback as... * {{cite book |date=1997 |title=The Trail of Lot 163: In Search of Lost Art Treasures |location=London |publisher=Fourth Estate |isbn=978-1857025231 }} * {{cite book |date=2009 |title=Sleuth: The Amazing Quest for Lost Art Treasures |location=London |publisher=HarperCollins |isbn=978-0007281367 }}, retitled for US edition as... ** {{cite book |date=2010 |title=The Art Detective: Fakes, Frauds and Finds and the Search for Lost Treasures |location=New York |publisher=Viking |isbn=978-0670021857 }}
== Personal life == Philip Mould lives with his wife Catherine and son Oliver at their house in [[Kensington]], London and a seventeenth-century manor house in Oxfordshire close to [[Chipping Norton]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Period Property |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/property/periodproperty/8731501/BBC-presenter-Philip-Moulds-Duck-End-house-Oxfordshire.html |title=BBC presenter Philip Mould's Duck End house, Oxfordshire |publisher=''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' |date= |accessdate=9 October 2015}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
== External links == * {{Official website|http://www.philipmould.com}} * {{Twitter}} * {{Journalisted|philip-mould}} * [https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=128305649 Philip Mould, ''The Art Detective''] at [[NPR]].org
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Mould, Philip}} [[Category:1960 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People educated at Worth School]] [[Category:Alumni of the University of East Anglia]] [[Category:English art dealers]] [[Category:Officers of the Order of the British Empire]] [[Category:BBC people]] [[Category:Fellows of the Linnean Society of London]] [[Category:Fake or Fortune?]]

'''Postglacial vegetation''' refers to plants that colonize the newly exposed substrate after a [[Holocene glacial retreat|glacial retreat]].<ref>Bennett, p. 699.</ref> The term "postglacial" typically refers to processes and events that occur after the departure of [[Glacier|glacial ice]] or glacial [[climate]]s.<ref>Ritchie, p. 6.</ref>
[[File:Handies Peak WSA (9466436592).jpg|thumb|Handies Peak WSA (9466436592)]]
== Climate Influence == Climate change is the main force behind changes in species distribution and abundance. Repeated changes in climate throughout the [[Quaternary]] Period are thought to have had a significant impact on the current vegetative species diversity present today.<ref>Bennett, K.D., 1988, Post-glacial vegetation history: ecological considerations, Kluwer Academic Publishers, Handbook of Vegetation science, vol.7, pp.699-724</ref> Functional and [[phylogenetic]] diversity are considered to be closely related to changing climatic conditions, this indicates that trait differences are extremely important in long term responses to climate change. During the transition from the last glaciation of the [[Pleistocene]] to the [[Holocene period]], climate warming resulted in the expansion of taller plants and larger seed bearing plants which resulted in lower proportions of vegetative regeneration.<ref>Reitalu, T., Gerhold, P., Poska, A., Pärtel, M., Väli, V., Veski, S. (2015), Novel insights into post-glacial vegetation change: functional and phylogenetic diversity in pollen records. Journal of Vegetation Science, v. 26, p. 911–22.</ref> Hence, low temperatures can be strong environmental filters that prevent tall and large-seeded plants from establishing in postglacial environments.<ref>Reitalu, T., Gerhold, P., Poska, A., Pärtel, M., Väli, V., Veski, S. (2015), Novel insights into post-glacial vegetation change: functional and phylogenetic diversity in pollen records. Journal of Vegetation Science, v. 26, p. 911–22.</ref> Throughout Europe vegetation dynamics within the first half of the Holocene appear to have been influenced mainly by climate and the reorganization of atmospheric circulation associated with the disappearance of the North American ice sheet. This is evident in the rapid increase of forestation and changing biomes during the postglacial period between 11500ka and 8000ka before the present.<ref>Davis, B., Collins, P.M., Kaplan, J.O., 2014 (July), The age and post-glacial development of the modern European vegetation: a plant functional approach based on pollen data, Springer-Verlag, Berlin Heidelberg, DOI 10.1007/s00334-014-0476-9</ref> Vegetation development periods of post-glacial land forms on [[Ellesmere Island]], Northern Canada, is assumed to have been at least ca. 20,000 years in duration. This slow progression is mostly due to climatic restrictions such as an estimated annual rainfall amount of only 64mm and a mean annual temperature of -19.7 degrees Celsius. The length in time of vegetation development observed on Ellesmere Island is evidence that post glacial vegetation development is much more restricted in the Arctic and colder climates as compared to milder climatic regions such as the boreal, temperate and tropical zones.<ref>Okitsu, S., Sawaguchi, S., Hasegawa, H., Kanda, H., 2004, Vegetation development on the glacier moraines in Oobloyah Valley, Ellesmere Island, high arctic Canada, National Institute of Polar Research, Polar Biosci., 17, 83-94</ref>
== Vegetation Responses == As land became exposed following the glaciation of the last ice age, a variety of geographic settings ranging from the tropics to the Arctic and Antarctic became available for the establishment of vegetation. Species that now exist on formerly glaciated terrain must have undergone a change in distribution of hundreds to thousands of kilometers, or have evolved from other [[taxa]] that have once done so in the past.<ref>Bennett, K.D., 1988, Post-glacial vegetation history: ecological considerations, Kluwer Academic Publishers, Handbook of Vegetation science, vol.7, pp.699-724</ref> In a newly developing environment, plant growth is often strongly influenced by the introduction of new organisms into that environment, where competitive or mutuallistic relationships may develop. Often, competitive balances are eventually reached and species abundances remain somewhat constant over a period of generations. Studies done on the Norwegian Island of [[Svalbard]], have been very useful in understanding the behavior of postglacial vegetation. Studies show that many vascular plants that are considered pioneers of vegetation development, eventually become less frequent. For example, the abundance of species such as [[Braya purpurascens]] has fallen nearly 30% due to the introduction of new species in the area.<ref>5. Moreau, M., Laffly, D. and Brossard, T. (2009), Recent spatial development of Svalbard strandflat vegetation over a period of 31 years. Polar Research, v. 28, p. 364–375.</ref>
== Postglacial Vegetation in North America == Arctic vegetation has distinct postglacial development characteristics compared to more temperate zones of lower latitudes. A study of postglacial moraines conducted in the Canadian Arctic on Ellesmere Island have found that dwarf shrubs of Dryas integrifolia and Cassiope tetragona are often good indicators of vegetation development and progression. Dwarf shrubs have been found to increase with the age of the moraine, with Dryas integrifolia becoming the most predominant. As well the cover of vegetation, including lichens and [[bryophytes]] showed consistent increase with the moraine age, suggesting directional vegetation development.<ref>Okitsu, S., Sawaguchi, S., Hasegawa, H., Kanda, H., 2004, Vegetation development on the glacier moraines in Oobloyah Valley, Ellesmere Island, high arctic Canada, National Institute of Polar Research, Polar Biosci., 17, 83-94</ref> It is also suggested that part of the high proportions of polypoids occurring in arctic floras is the result of speciation as continental ice-sheets withdrew.<ref>Bennett, K.D., 1988, Post-glacial vegetation history: ecological considerations, Kluwer Academic Publishers, Handbook of Vegetation science, vol.7, pp.699-724</ref> Pollen diagrams from northern Quebec, Canada, show advances throughout the Holocene of post-glacial vegetation development. The initial phase of open vegetation began about 6000 years before the present. Following deglaciation, shrub and herbaceous tundra plants dominated for a brief period of time. Plants such as the Larix laricina, Populus and [[Juniperus]], were also important in the initial vegetation development. Some species that followed later include: Alnus crispa, and [[Betula]]. Though later vegetation development was mainly dominated by [[Picea]], shortly following deglaciation, they reached their present day limit. Today black spruce is mainly dominant throughout much of northern Quebec.<ref>Gawjewski, Konrad., Garralla, Silvina., and Milot-roy, Valerie., Postglacial vegetation at the Northern Limit of Lichen Woodland in Northwestern Quebec, 1996, Geographie Physique et Quarternaire, v 50(3). P. 341-350</ref> Continental U.S. is considered to have strongly contributed to the re-establishment of postglacial vegetation in Canada following the last ice age. Roughly 300 taxa of vascular plants and mosses that were found to have existed below the extent of the last glacial period within the United States are also found to have migrated to Canada. These patterns are recorded within either pollen or macro fossils.<ref>Ritchie, J.C.,1987, Postglacial Vegetation of Canada, Cambridge University Press, {{ISBN|0521544092}}.</ref>
== Anthropogenic Impact == Studies done by Reitalu, (2015) have found that human impact throughout much of Europe has negatively influenced plant diversity by suppressing the establishment of tall-growing, large seeded taxa. Although human influence has facilitated many Ruderal species, this is believed to have led to an overall decrease in phylogenetic diversity.<ref>Reitalu, T., Gerhold, P., Poska, A., Pärtel, M., Väli, V., Veski, S. (2015), Novel insights into post-glacial vegetation change: functional and phylogenetic diversity in pollen records. Journal of Vegetation Science, v. 26, p. 911–22.</ref>
== Research Methods == Many pollen diagrams around the world indicate that major climate changes caused the last continental ice sheets to retreat, leading to dramatic effects on the distribution and abundance of plants.<ref>Bennett, K.D., 1988, Post-glacial vegetation history: ecological considerations, Kluwer Academic Publishers, Handbook of Vegetation science, vol.7, pp.699-724</ref> By converting pollen data into plant functional type (PFT) assemblages and interpolating the data, researchers have been able to reconstruct postglacial vegetation patterns around the world.<ref>Davis, B., Collins, P.M., Kaplan, J.O., 2014 (July), The age and post-glacial development of the modern European vegetation: a plant functional approach based on pollen data, Springer-Verlag, Berlin Heidelberg, DOI 10.1007/s00334-014-0476-9</ref> Core sampling and analysis of lake sediments that contain pollen and other plant remains are often used to obtain good records of past pollination cycles. Such paleorecords preserved in lake sediments can be used to reconstruct the history of post glacial vegetation.<ref>Seppä, H., Cwynar, L. C. and MacDonald, G. M. (2003), Post-glacial vegetation reconstruction and a possible 8200 cal. yr BP event from the low arctic of continental Nunavut, Canada. J. Quaternary Sci., 18: 621–629. doi: 10.1002/jqs.793</ref> Lake sediments have an advantage over other core sampling sites, such as fen and bog peats, as they provide no overwhelming local pollen components. As well, lake sediments contain stratigraphic changes in soil character, which are useful for understanding changes in vegetation development over a period of time.<ref>Pennington, W., (1965). The Interpretation of Some Post-Glacial Vegetation Diversities at Different Lake District Sites. Proceedings of the Royal Society of London. Series B, Biological Sciences, v. 161(984), p. 310-323.</ref> Macrofossils that are obtained from sedimentary deposits are also useful for constructing the history of changing postglacial vegetation.<ref>Moore, D. M. (1978), Post-glacial vegetation in the South Patagonian territory of the giant ground sloth, Mylodon. Botanical Journal of the Linnean Society, 77: 177–202. doi: 10.1111/j.1095-8339.1978.tb01398.x</ref>
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==References== * {{cite web | url=https://www.academia.edu/1419118/Post-glacial_vegetation_history_ecological_considerations | title=Post-glacial vegetation history: ecological considerations | publisher=Handbook of Vegetation Science | work=Volume 7 | date=1988 | accessdate=January 3, 2013 | author=Bennett, Keith | pages=699–724}} * {{cite book |title=Post-glacial Vegetation of Canada |last=Ritchie |first=J. C. |authorlink= |coauthors= |year=2004 |publisher=Cambridge University Press |location= |isbn=0521544092 |page= |pages= |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=B7y3l0QVETgC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Postglacial+vegetation&hl=en&sa=X&ei=2fHlUMORIM3oigK6mIGgAw&ved=0CDQQ6AEwAA |accessdate=January 2013}}
==Further reading== * {{cite book |title=Boundary Waters: Wilderness Ecosystem |last=Heinselman |first=Miron |authorlink= |coauthors= |year=1999 |publisher=U of Minnesota Press |location= |isbn=081662805X |page= |pages=34–36 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=L8bIC7y0LGoC&pg=PA36&dq=Postglacial+vegetation&hl=en&sa=X&ei=2fHlUMORIM3oigK6mIGgAw&ved=0CF8Q6AEwCA#v=onepage&q=Postglacial%20vegetation&f=false |accessdate=January 2013}} * {{cite book |title=Late-glacial and postglacial vegetation history of Cape Cod and the paleolimnology of Duck Pond, South Wellfleet, Massachusetts |last=Winkler |first=Marjorie Green |authorlink= |coauthors= |year=1982 |publisher=University of Wisconsin-Madison, |location= |isbn= |page= |pages= |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EIBmAAAAMAAJ&q=Postglacial+vegetation&dq=Postglacial+vegetation&hl=en&sa=X&ei=2fHlUMORIM3oigK6mIGgAw&ved=0CDoQ6AEwAQ |accessdate=January 2013}}
